tags.name: Cloud Data Fabric
tags.description: The Cloud Data Fabric functionality lets clusters across disparate geographic or infrastructural locations access the same data while maintaining independent namespace structures on each cluster. To enable Cloud Data Fabric functionality, you must define a spoke portal on on cluster, a hub portal on another cluster, and then propose a relationship between the two.

signing.description:
Setting for DCERPC signing; only use if sealing is not negotiated:
 * `NO_SIGNING` - Do not use DCERPC signing.,
 * `REQUIRE_SIGNING` - Require the use of DCERPC signing.,
 * `WANT_SIGNING` - Prefer to use DCERPC signing; allow server to decide.

sealing.description:
Setting for DCERPC sealing.:
 * `NO_SEALING` - Do not use sealing.,
 * `REQUIRE_SEALING` - Require the use of sealing.,
 * `WANT_SEALING` - Prefer to use sealing; allow server to decide.

crypto.description:
Setting for authenticator and sealing crypto.:
 * `NO_AES` - Do not use AES.,
 * `REQUIRE_AES` - Require the use of AES.,
 * `WANT_AES` - Prefer use of AES; allow server to decide.

capacity_clamp.description: The value, in bytes, to clamp usable capacity to

get.summary: Retrieve the capacity clamp value in bytes. You can set this value by using a PUT API call or as an argument to the cluster creation API. The cluster uses this value to determine the maximum capacity that it can provision, regardless of the maximum capacity of the underlying storage.

put.summary: Specify the capacity clamp value in bytes. This value limits maximum provisioned capacity. The actual provisioned space is limited to the maximum capacity of the underlying storage. In addition, the actual provisioned space is close to the requested value in bytes, without exceeding it. If the system applies this value successfully, it abandons quorum and allocates storage capacity in a new quorum.

get.summary: Gets detailed status information for the data protection of the cluster.

state.description:
Restriper state (one of NOT_STARTED, RUNNING, FINISHED).:
 * `FINISHED` - FINISHED,
 * `NOT_STARTED` - NOT_STARTED,
 * `RUNNING` - RUNNING

phase.description:
Restriper phase when state is RUNNING (one of PLANNING, REPROTECT, REBALANCE, PARTITIONED_REBALANCE, TRANSCODE). Empty otherwise.:
 * `PARTITIONED_REBALANCE` - PARTITIONED_REBALANCE,
 * `PLANNING` - PLANNING,
 * `REBALANCE` - REBALANCE,
 * `REPROTECT` - REPROTECT,
 * `TRANSCODE` - TRANSCODE

blocked_reason.description: If state is FINISHED but restriper did not complete all required work, this field provides the reason for the work being incomplete. Empty otherwise.

data_at_risk.description: True if any data is not fully protected, false otherwise.

elapsed_seconds.description: Elapsed time since the current phase began (0 if state is not RUNNING).

percent_complete.description: Percent completion of the current phase (0 if state is not RUNNING).

coordinator_node.description: Restriper coordinator node ID in this quorum, where reports are being recorded.

id.description: Node:Slot representation identifying the slot

node_id.description: Integer ID of the node containing the slot.

slot.description: Integer ID of slot on the given node

state.description:
Disk slot state (healthy, dead, empty):
 * `dead` - API_DEVICE_UI_STATE_DEAD,
 * `empty` - API_DEVICE_UI_STATE_EMPTY,
 * `healthy` - API_DEVICE_UI_STATE_HEALTHY,
 * `missing` - API_DEVICE_UI_STATE_MISSING,
 * `wrong_cluster` - API_DEVICE_UI_STATE_WRONG_CLUSTER,
 * `wrong_node` - API_DEVICE_UI_STATE_WRONG_NODE,
 * `wrong_version` - API_DEVICE_UI_STATE_WRONG_VERSION

slot_type.description:
Device type for slot (SSD, HDD):
 * `Ephemeral SSD` - API_DEVICE_SLOT_TYPE_EPHEMERAL_SSD,
 * `HDD` - API_DEVICE_SLOT_TYPE_SPINNING_DISK,
 * `Premium Page Blob` - API_DEVICE_SLOT_TYPE_PREMIUM_PAGE_BLOB,
 * `SSD` - API_DEVICE_SLOT_TYPE_SSD,
 * `Standard Page Blob` - API_DEVICE_SLOT_TYPE_STANDARD_PAGE_BLOB,
 * `Write Tier SSD` - API_DEVICE_SLOT_TYPE_WRITE_TIER_SSD

disk_type.description:
Type of disk, if present (SSD, HDD):
 * `` - API_DEVICE_MEDIA_TYPE_MISSING,
 * `DEVICE_MEDIA_TYPE_UNKNOWN` - API_DEVICE_MEDIA_TYPE_UNKNOWN,
 * `Ephemeral SSD` - The device type of a disk used for the read cache on object-backed clusters,
 * `HDD` - API_DEVICE_MEDIA_TYPE_SPINNING_DISK,
 * `Premium Page Blob` - API_DEVICE_MEDIA_TYPE_PREMIUM_PAGE_BLOB,
 * `SSD` - API_DEVICE_MEDIA_TYPE_SSD,
 * `Standard Page Blob` - API_DEVICE_MEDIA_TYPE_STANDARD_PAGE_BLOB,
 * `Write Tier SSD` - The device type of a disk used for the write cache on object-backed clusters

capacity.description: Capacity in bytes (0 if slot is empty)

raw_capacity.description: Raw capacity in bytes (0 if slot is empty)

minimum_raw_capacity.description: Minimum raw capacity in bytes for slot

high_endurance.description: Is this device a high endurance model

led_pattern.description:
Current state of the slot's LED:
 * `LED_PATTERN_FAILURE` - failure,
 * `LED_PATTERN_LOCATE` - locate,
 * `LED_PATTERN_NORMAL` - normal

 * `Standard Page Blob` - API_DEVICE_MEDIA_TYPE_STANDARD_PAGE_BLOB,

get.summary: Return the contents of the file as an HTTP octet stream. The etag returned by this method represents the whole state of this file. In another word, if you are reading just a portion of the data, etag could be invalid because of other changes happened to the file, even the specific portion of data you read is still intact.

source_id.description: File ID of the source file. Exactly one of source_id or source_path must be provided.

source_path.description: Path of the source file. Exactly one of source_id or source_path must be provided.

source_stream_id.description: Stream ID of the source file. Defaults to default stream.

source_snapshot.description: Snapshot ID specifying the version of the file to copy from. Defaults to head version.

source_offset.description: Specifies the offset in bytes to start copying from. Defaults to 0.

target_offset.description: Specifies the offset in bytes to start copying to. Defaults to 0.

length.description: Specifies the maximum length of copy in bytes. Defaults to copy to the end of the source file. The server may not be able to copy the entire length requested. If that is the case, the response body returned can be used as request body for the remaining copy.

source_etag.description: Expected ETag of the source file returned from /v1/files/{source-id}/info/attributes. If provided, this ETag will be validated against the server to ensure no intermediate change has occurred.

post.summary: Create a new file, link, or directory. In addition, this method can be use to rename an existing file. The return value is an attribute structure for the new file; refer to the 'Set Attributes' method for field descriptions.

action.description:
Operation to perform:
 * `CREATE_DIRECTORY` - API_FILES_CREATE_DIRECTORY,
 * `CREATE_FILE` - API_FILES_CREATE_FILE,
 * `CREATE_LINK` - API_FILES_CREATE_LINK,
 * `CREATE_SYMLINK` - API_FILES_CREATE_SYMLINK,
 * `CREATE_UNIX_FILE` - API_FILES_CREATE_UNIX_FILE,
 * `RENAME` - API_FILES_RENAME

clobber.description: When action is RENAME, setting this to true will clobber the destination if it exists.

symlink_target_type.description:
The file type of the target to which the symbolic link points. If you don't specify the file type, or if it is FS_FILE_TYPE_UNKNOWN, the effect is the same as running the 'ln -s' command on a Unix NFS client. If the file type is FS_FILE_TYPE_FILE or FS_FILE_TYPE_DIRECTORY, the effect is the same as running the 'mklink' or 'mklink /D' command on a Windows SMB client.:
 * `FS_FILE_TYPE_DIRECTORY` - API_SYMLINK_TARGET_DIRECTORY,
 * `FS_FILE_TYPE_FILE` - API_SYMLINK_TARGET_FILE,
 * `FS_FILE_TYPE_UNKNOWN` - API_SYMLINK_TARGET_UNKNOWN

unix_file_type.description:
Required when the action is CREATE_UNIX_FILE. You are given the choice of FS_FILE_TYPE_UNIX_BLOCK_DEVICE, FS_FILE_TYPE_UNIX_CHARACTER_DEVICE, FS_FILE_TYPE_UNIX_PIPE or FS_FILE_TYPE_UNIX_SOCKET:
 * `FS_FILE_TYPE_DIRECTORY` - FS_FILE_TYPE_DIRECTORY,
 * `FS_FILE_TYPE_FILE` - FS_FILE_TYPE_FILE,
 * `FS_FILE_TYPE_SYMLINK` - FS_FILE_TYPE_SYMLINK,

 * `FS_FILE_TYPE_UNIX_SOCKET` - FS_FILE_TYPE_UNIX_SOCKET

post.summary: Explain the derived POSIX mode for a file/directory.

parameters.name: ref
parameters.description: The file ID or the absolute path to the file system object. File IDs can be found in the id field of responses of APIs that return file attributes. You must URL-encode the paths. The APIs & Tools page in the Qumulo Core Web UI URL-encodes the paths.

schema.description: The file ID or the absolute path to the file system object. File IDs can be found in the id field of responses of APIs that return file attributes. You must URL-encode the paths. The APIs & Tools page in the Qumulo Core Web UI URL-encodes the paths.

parameters.description: The snapshot ID that specifies the version of the filesystem to use. If not specified, use the head version.

parameters.name: recursive
parameters.description: Specifies whether notifications are recursive. A recursive notification emits events for all files in the entire directory tree of the specified directory. A non-recursive notification emits events only for files that are immediately below (but not further down the directory tree) for the specified directory. To configure recursion for notifications, use the /v1/file-system/settings/notify REST API resource.

schema.description: Specifies whether notifications are recursive. A recursive notification emits events for all files in the entire directory tree of the specified directory. A non-recursive notification emits events only for files that are immediately below (but not further down the directory tree) for the specified directory. To configure recursion for notifications, use the /v1/file-system/settings/notify REST API resource.

get.summary: Streams notifications for file system activity, monitoring only the files in the specified directory by using HTML server-sent events (SSE). The SSE data payload contains JSON-encoded event objects. For example: [{"type": <string>, "path": <string>, "stream_name": <optional string>}].

source_id.description: File ID of the source file. Exactly one of source_id or source_path must be provided.

source_path.description: Path of the source file. Exactly one of source_id or source_path must be provided.

source_stream_id.description: Stream ID of the source file. Defaults to default stream.

source_snapshot.description: Snapshot ID specifying the version of the file to copy from. Defaults to head version.

source_offset.description: Specifies the offset in bytes to start copying from. Defaults to 0.

target_offset.description: Specifies the offset in bytes to start copying to. Defaults to 0.

length.description: Specifies the maximum length of copy in bytes. Defaults to copy to the end of the source file. The server may not be able to copy the entire length requested. If that is the case, the response body returned can be used as request body for the remaining copy.

source_etag.description: Expected ETag of the source file returned from /v1/files/{source-id}/info/attributes. If provided, this ETag will be validated against the server to ensure no intermediate change has occurred.

get.summary: Return the contents of the file as an HTTP octet stream. The etag returned by this method represents the whole state of this file. use_ldap.description: Top-level LDAP enablement switch, indicating whether Qumulo Core should use LDAP or not.

bind_uri.description: LDAP server URIs (for example, ldap://example.com). Separate multiple URIs with commas (,).

user.description: Binding user's distinguished name. Default is empty, for anonymous authentication.

password.description: Binding password for simple auth. Default is the password that is currently configured.

base_distinguished_names.description: Distinguished name(s) which will be used as the search base for queries. Multiple DNs may be specified, separated by semi-colons. Example: dc=users,dc=example,dc=com; dc=robots,dc=example,dc=com

ldap_schema.description:
LDAP server schema to use. Default is RFC2307:
 * `CUSTOM` - CUSTOM,
 * `RFC2307` - RFC2307

ldap_schema_description.description: An expanded description of the LDAP server schema. Only set this field if setting ldap_schema to CUSTOM.

encrypt_connection.description: If true, require to have encrypted connection with LDAP. Default is True.

required_authentication_mode.description:
The authentication mode hosts are required to authenticate with.:
 * `AUTHENTICATION_MODE_KRB5` - Require users to authenticate with the krb5 security flavor.,
 * `AUTHENTICATION_MODE_KRB5I` - Require users to authenticate with the krb5i security flavor.,
 * `AUTHENTICATION_MODE_KRB5P` - Require users to authenticate with the krb5p security flavor.,
 * `AUTHENTICATION_MODE_NONE` - Allow unauthenticated access.

user_mapping.description:
NFS user mapping (squashing) support:
 * `NFS_MAP_ALL` - Map all users.,
 * `NFS_MAP_NONE` - Do not map users.,
 * `NFS_MAP_ROOT` - Map root user (uid 0).

map_to_user.description: An identity object representing a local user or an NFS user to map (see /users). If map_to_user is an NFS user, then map_to_group with an NFS gid must be given.

fields_to_present_as_32_bit.description: Specify which NFS3 result values should be 32-bit sanitized on this export. Has no effect on exports used over NFS4.

items.description:
Specify which NFS3 result values should be 32-bit sanitized on this export. Has no effect on exports used over NFS4.:
 * `ALL` - Force all 64 bit fields to fit in 32 bits.,
 * `FILE_IDS` - Hash high file ids to 32 bits.,
 * `FILE_SIZES` - Clamp large file sizes to 4GiB to fit in 32 bits.,
 * `FS_SIZE` - Clamp available, used and total space reported for the FS to 4GiB.

 * `NFS_MAP_ALL` - Map all users.,
 * `NFS_MAP_NONE` - Do not map users.,
 * `NFS_MAP_ROOT` - Map root user (uid 0).

map_to_user.description: An identity object representing a local user or an NFS user to map (see /users). If map_to_user is an NFS user, then map_to_group with an NFS gid must be given.

id_type.description:
id_type:
 * `INTERNAL` - INTERNAL,
 * `LOCAL_GROUP` - LOCAL_GROUP,
 * `LOCAL_USER` - LOCAL_USER,
 * `NFS_GID` - NFS_GID,
 * `NFS_UID` - NFS_UID,
 * `QUMULO_OPERATOR` - QUMULO_OPERATOR,
 * `QUMULO_SUPPORT` - QUMULO_SUPPORT,
 * `SMB_SID` - SMB_SID

map_to_group.description: An identity object representing an NFS group. If given, map_to_user should be an NFS user.

id_type.description:
id_type:
 * `INTERNAL` - INTERNAL,
 * `LOCAL_GROUP` - LOCAL_GROUP,
 * `LOCAL_USER` - LOCAL_USER,
 * `NFS_GID` - NFS_GID,
 * `NFS_UID` - NFS_UID,
 * `QUMULO_OPERATOR` - QUMULO_OPERATOR,
 * `QUMULO_SUPPORT` - QUMULO_SUPPORT,
 * `SMB_SID` - SMB_SID

fields_to_present_as_32_bit.description: Specify which NFS3 result values should be 32-bit sanitized on this export. Has no effect on exports used over NFS4

items.description:
Specify which NFS3 result values should be 32-bit sanitized on this export. Has no effect on exports used over NFS4:
 * `ALL` - Force all 64 bit fields to fit in 32 bits.,
 * `FILE_IDS` - Hash high file ids to 32 bits.,
 * `FILE_SIZES` - Clamp large file sizes to 4GiB to fit in 32 bits.,
 * `FS_SIZE` - Clamp available, used and total space reported for the FS to 4GiB.

 * `FILE_IDS` - Hash high file ids to 32 bits.,
 * `FILE_SIZES` - Clamp large file sizes to 4GiB to fit in 32 bits.,
 * `FS_SIZE` - Clamp available, used and total space reported for the FS to 4GiB.

cable_status.description:
Whether network card is connected via cable.:
 * `CONNECTED` - NETWORK_CABLE_CONNECTED,
 * `DISCONNECTED` - NETWORK_CABLE_DISCONNECTED,
 * `UNKNOWN` - NETWORK_CABLE_UNKNOWN

interface_status.description:
Status of interface connection.:
 * `DORMANT` - NETWORK_INTERFACE_DORMANT,
 * `DOWN` - NETWORK_INTERFACE_DOWN,
 * `LOWERLAYERDOWN` - NETWORK_INTERFACE_LOWER_LAYER_DOWN,
 * `MISSING` - NETWORK_INTERFACE_MISSING,
 * `NOTPRESENT` - NETWORK_INTERFACE_NOT_PRESENT,
 * `TESTING` - NETWORK_INTERFACE_TESTING,
 * `UNKNOWN` - NETWORK_INTERFACE_UNKNOWN,
 * `UP` - NETWORK_INTERFACE_UP

timestamp.description: UNIX epoch timestamp for when the network status was sampled.

 * `IEEE_8023AD` - BONDING_MODE_IEEE_8023AD

node_id.description: node-id of the node responding to the get

state.description:
The state of the node:
 * `ACTIVE` - Configured node part of active quorum,
 * `PAUSED` - Configured node part of paused quorum,
 * `REMOVED` - Configured node that has been removed from its cluster,
 * `STOPPED` - Configured node not part of quorum,
 * `UNCONFIGURED` - Unconfigured node

cluster_id.description: Unique identifier of cluster the node belongs to or the empty string ('') if the node is unconfigured

get.summary: Retrieves node state of the node that the call was made to.
Retrieve the list of object storage URIs which point to the location where the system stores object-backed data.

post.summary: Add new object storage URIs to the list of object storage URIs which point to the location where the system stores object-backed data. If this endpoint is called with URIs which are already in use, the system adds new URIs to the list of object storage URIs and ignores the existing URIs. Although the system does not rebalance data across URIs, it allocates new space to the least-used URIs.

id.description: Unique identifier of the replication relationship

target_port.description: Network port to replicate to on the target

source_root_id.description: File ID of the source directory

source_root_read_only.description: Whether the source directory is read-only

map_local_ids_to_nfs_ids.description: Whether to map local user/group identities to their associated NFS UID/GID when replicating them to the target cluster. Replication of local identities fails if this option is false

replication_mode.description:
Whether to replicate continuously, replicate snapshots from linked snapshot policies, or both:
 * `REPLICATION_CONTINUOUS` - REPLICATION_CONTINUOUS,
 * `REPLICATION_SNAPSHOT_POLICY` - REPLICATION_SNAPSHOT_POLICY,
 * `REPLICATION_SNAPSHOT_POLICY_WITH_CONTINUOUS` - REPLICATION_SNAPSHOT_POLICY_WITH_CONTINUOUS

items.description: List of blackout windows for the relationship

start_hour.description: Hour of day [0, 23] at which the blackout window begins

start_minute.description: Minute of hour [0, 59] at which the blackout window begins

end_hour.description: Hour of day [0, 23] at which the blackout window ends

end_minute.description: Minute of hour [0, 59] at which the blackout window ends

on_days.description: List of days of the week on which the replication schedule applies. Choose from SUN, MON, TUE, WED, THU, FRI, and/or SAT. EVERY_DAY can be used to specify all days.

 * `EVERY_DAY` - EVERY_DAY,
 * `FRI` - FRI,
 * `MON` - MON,
 * `SAT` - SAT,
 * `SUN` - SUN,
 * `THU` - THU,
 * `TUE` - TUE,
 * `WED` - WED
List of snapshot policies linked with the relationship along with the corresponding expiration time of the replicated snapshots on the target for each linked policy

id.description: Unique identifier for the snapshot policy linked with the relationship

target_expiration.description: Duration after which to expire snapshots on the target cluster that were replicated from this snapshot policy, in format <quantity><units>, where <quantity> is a positive integer less than 100 and <units> is one of [months, weeks, days, hours, minutes], e.g. 5days or 1hours. 'never' indicates snapshots should never expire and 'same_as_policy' indicates snapshots should expire at the same time as the snapshot policy specifies.

post.summary: Create a new replication relationship with this cluster as the source. To begin replication, the corresponding relationship on the target cluster must be authorized using the authorize API.

state.description:
Current state of replication relationship:
 * `AWAITING_AUTHORIZATION` - AWAITING_AUTHORIZATION,
 * `DISCONNECTED` - DISCONNECTED,
 * `DISCONNECTING` - DISCONNECTING,
 * `ENDED` - ENDED,

end_reason.description: If the relationship has ENDED, this states the reason. Otherwise, this field is empty

target_root_read_only.description: Whether the target directory is read-only

job_state.description:
Current state of the job:
 * `REPLICATION_NOT_RUNNING` - REPLICATION_NOT_RUNNING,
 * `REPLICATION_RUNNING` - REPLICATION_RUNNING

job_start_time.description: If the job state is REPLICATION_RUNNING, this is the time that the job started, encoded as RFC 3339

recovery_point.description: The time that the last successful job started, encoded as RFC 3339

error_from_last_job.description: The error message from the previous job. If the previous job succeeded or no job has ever run, this field will be empty

duration_of_last_job.description: The elapsed execution time of the previous job, in nanoseconds. If no job has ever run, this field will be null.

source_root_id.description: File ID of the source directory

next_active_time.description: The time when the current blackout period ends (in UTC). If replication is currently enabled and not in a blackout period, this field will be empty

replication_job_status.description: Information about the progress of a job. This field is null if there is no job status available.

percent_complete.description: Percent of way through the job, computed from a weighting of data and files processed

estimated_seconds_remaining.description: Estimated number of seconds remaining in the job, derived from percent_complete. This may be null if there is no estimate.

bytes_unchanged.description: Number of bytes not copied because they didn't change

bytes_remaining.description: Number of bytes left to be processed in order to complete this job

bytes_total.description: Total number of bytes that will be processed during this job (this will be close but not exact)

files_unchanged.description: Number of files not copied because they didn't change

files_remaining.description: Number of files left to be processed in order to complete this job

files_total.description: Total number of files that will be processed during this job (this will be close but not exact)

throughput_overall.description: Overall average throughput in bytes per second of data copied since the beginning of the job

throughput_current.description: Average throughput in bytes per second of data copied in the last one minute

queued_snapshot_count.description: The number of snapshots from linked snapshot policies awaiting replication by this relationship

recovery_point_snapshot.description: The snapshot replicated by the last successful job. This field is null if no job has ever run successfully.

id.description: Unique identifier of the snapshot

timestamp.description: Creation timestamp of the snapshot, encoded as RFC 3339, which is a normalized subset of ISO 8601. See http://tools.ietf.org/rfc/rfc3339.txt, section 5.6 for ABNF.

directory_name.description: Snapshot directory name, as would be seen in the .snapshot directory over SMB or NFS.

source_file_id.description: Source directory of the snapshot

created_by_policy.description: This snapshot was created by a policy. The name of that policy will be stored in the name field in place of a user-defined name.

expiration.description: Time at which snapshot will be expired. Empty string if no expiration time set. Encoded as RFC 3339, which is a normalized subset of ISO 8601. See http://tools.ietf.org/rfc/rfc3339.txt, section 5.6 for ABNF.

in_delete.description: Whether or not the snapshot is in the process of being deleted

replicating_snapshot.description: The snapshot that is being replicated by the current job. This field is null if no job is in progress.

post.summary: Reverse source and target for the specified replication relationship. This operation is initiated on the target cluster. The previous target directory will be made the new source, and the previous source directory will be made the new target. Any relationship configurations on the source will be retained, and any configurations on the target that have been retained from a previous reversal will be reapplied. To resume replication after reversal, edit any relationship configurations if desired and reconnect the relationship from the new target cluster.

target_relationship_id.description: The identifier of the target relationship to reverse

source_address.description: The IP address of the source cluster

source_port.description: Network port of the source cluster (defaults to 3712)

files_remaining.description: Number of files left to be processed in order to complete this job

files_total.description: Total number of files that will be processed during this job (this will be close but not exact)

throughput_overall.description: Overall average throughput in bytes per second of data copied since the beginning of the job

recovery_point_snapshot.description: The snapshot that the last successful job replicated. If no replication job has ever run successfully, this field is set to null.

id.description: Unique identifier of the snapshot

timestamp.description: Creation timestamp of the snapshot, encoded as RFC 3339, which is a normalized subset of ISO 8601. See http://tools.ietf.org/rfc/rfc3339.txt, section 5.6 for ABNF.

directory_name.description: Snapshot directory name, as would be seen in the .snapshot directory over SMB or NFS.

source_file_id.description: Source directory of the snapshot

created_by_policy.description: This snapshot was created by a policy. The name of that policy will be stored in the name field in place of a user-defined name.

expiration.description: Time at which snapshot will be expired. Empty string if no expiration time set. Encoded as RFC 3339, which is a normalized subset of ISO 8601. See http://tools.ietf.org/rfc/rfc3339.txt, section 5.6 for ABNF.

in_delete.description: Whether or not the snapshot is in the process of being deleted

lock_key.description: The key that locks the policy-created snapshots for the specified target replication relationship. If set to null, the system does not lock the snapshots that the specified target replication relationship creates. Only snapshots created by a policy will be locked. Unless you configure an expiration on the snapshot policy on the target cluster, the system does not lock snapshots. If you reverse the relationship (switch the source and the target), the new target does not use this lock key. To enable snapshot locking, you must configure the new target separately. However, if you revert the reversed relationship (return the source and target to their original assignments), the system preserves the original target replication relationship lock key. Unless you reverse the relationship, you cannot disable or delete a lock key while a target replication relationship uses the key. If you disable or delete a lock key while the relationship is reversed and you then revert the reversal, the original source-target relationship has no lock key until you configure a new one.

port.description: HTTPS port to use when communicating with the object store

 * `BUCKET_STYLE_VIRTUAL_HOSTED` - BUCKET_STYLE_VIRTUAL_HOSTED

post.summary: Create a new object replication relationship. Replication will automatically start after the relationship is created.

direction.description:
Whether data is to be copied to, or from, the object store:
 * `COPY_FROM_OBJECT` - COPY_FROM_OBJECT,
 * `COPY_TO_OBJECT` - COPY_TO_OBJECT

local_directory_id.description: File ID of the qumulo directory if local_directory_path is not provided

local_directory_path.description: Path of the qumulo directory if local_directory_id is not provided

object_store_address.description: S3-compatible server address. For Amazon S3, use s3.<region>.amazonaws.com (e.g., s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com).

port.description: HTTPS port to use when communicating with the object store (default: 443)

ca_certificate.description: Public certificate of the certificate authority to trust for connections to the object store, in PEM format (defaults to built-in trusted public CAs)

bucket.description: Bucket in the object store to use for this relationship

bucket_style.description:
Addressing style for requests to the bucket. Set to BUCKET_STYLE_PATH for path-style addressing or BUCKET_STYLE_VIRTUAL_HOSTED for virtual hosted-style (the default). For Amazon S3, virtual hosted-style is recommended as path-style is deprecated. Bucket names containing dots ('.') or characters that are not valid in domain names may require path-style. The object_store_address should not include the bucket name, regardless of addressing style.:
 * `BUCKET_STYLE_PATH` - BUCKET_STYLE_PATH,
 * `BUCKET_STYLE_VIRTUAL_HOSTED` - BUCKET_STYLE_VIRTUAL_HOSTED

object_folder.description: Folder to use in the object store bucket. A slash separator is automatically used to specify a 'folder' in a bucket. For example, a folder of 'example' and a file path (relative to the directory_path) of 'dir/file' will result in key 'example/dir/file'. Use empty value '' or '/' to replicate with the root of the bucket.

region.description: Region the bucket is located in

access_key_id.description: Access key ID to use when communicating with the object store

secret_access_key.description: Secret access key to use when communicating with the object store

id.description: Unique identifier of the replication relationship

target_port.description: Network port to replicate to on the target

source_root_id.description: File ID of the source directory

source_root_read_only.description: Whether the source directory is read-only

map_local_ids_to_nfs_ids.description: Whether to map local user/group identities to their associated NFS UID/GID when replicating them to the target cluster. Replication of local identities fails if this option is false

replication_mode.description:
Whether to replicate continuously, replicate snapshots from linked snapshot policies, or both:
 * `REPLICATION_CONTINUOUS` - REPLICATION_CONTINUOUS,
 * `REPLICATION_SNAPSHOT_POLICY` - REPLICATION_SNAPSHOT_POLICY,
 * `REPLICATION_SNAPSHOT_POLICY_WITH_CONTINUOUS` - REPLICATION_SNAPSHOT_POLICY_WITH_CONTINUOUS

blackout_window_timezone.description: The time zone in which the blackout windows should be interpreted (e.g, America/Los_Angeles or UTC)

items.description: List of blackout windows for the relationship

start_hour.description: Hour of day [0, 23] at which the blackout window begins

start_minute.description: Minute of hour [0, 59] at which the blackout window begins

end_hour.description: Hour of day [0, 23] at which the blackout window ends

end_minute.description: Minute of hour [0, 59] at which the blackout window ends

on_days.description: List of days of the week on which the replication schedule applies. Choose from SUN, MON, TUE, WED, THU, FRI, and/or SAT. EVERY_DAY can be used to specify all days.

items.description:
List of days of the week on which the replication schedule applies. Choose from SUN, MON, TUE, WED, THU, FRI, and/or SAT. EVERY_DAY can be used to specify all days.:
 * `EVERY_DAY` - EVERY_DAY,
 * `FRI` - FRI,

 * `SAT` - SAT,
 * `SUN` - SUN,
 * `THU` - THU,
 * `TUE` - TUE,
 * `WED` - WED
List of snapshot policies linked with the relationship along with the corresponding expiration time of the replicated snapshots on the target for each linked policy

id.description: Unique identifier for the snapshot policy linked with the relationship

target_expiration.description: Duration after which to expire snapshots on the target cluster that were replicated from this snapshot policy, in format <quantity><units>, where <quantity> is a positive integer less than 100 and <units> is one of [months, weeks, days, hours, minutes], e.g. 5days or 1hours. 'never' indicates snapshots should never expire and 'same_as_policy' indicates snapshots should expire at the same time as the snapshot policy specifies.

state.description:
Current state of replication relationship:

 * `DISCONNECTED` - DISCONNECTED,
 * `DISCONNECTING` - DISCONNECTING,
 * `ENDED` - ENDED,
 * `ESTABLISHED` - ESTABLISHED,

 * `REESTABLISHING` - REESTABLISHING

end_reason.description: If the relationship has ENDED, this states the reason. Otherwise, this field is empty

target_root_read_only.description: Whether the target directory is read-only

job_state.description:
Current state of the job:
 * `REPLICATION_NOT_RUNNING` - REPLICATION_NOT_RUNNING,
 * `REPLICATION_RUNNING` - REPLICATION_RUNNING

job_start_time.description: If the job state is REPLICATION_RUNNING, this is the time that the job started, encoded as RFC 3339

recovery_point.description: The time that the last successful job started, encoded as RFC 3339

error_from_last_job.description: The error message from the previous job. If the previous job succeeded or no job has ever run, this field will be empty

duration_of_last_job.description: The elapsed execution time of the previous job, in nanoseconds. If no job has ever run, this field will be null.

source_root_id.description: File ID of the source directory

next_active_time.description: The time when the current blackout period ends (in UTC). If replication is currently enabled and not in a blackout period, this field will be empty

replication_job_status.description: Information about the progress of a job. This field is null if there is no job status available.

percent_complete.description: Percent of way through the job, computed from a weighting of data and files processed

estimated_seconds_remaining.description: Estimated number of seconds remaining in the job, derived from percent_complete. This may be null if there is no estimate.

bytes_unchanged.description: Number of bytes not copied because they didn't change

bytes_remaining.description: Number of bytes left to be processed in order to complete this job

bytes_total.description: Total number of bytes that will be processed during this job (this will be close but not exact)

files_unchanged.description: Number of files not copied because they didn't change

files_remaining.description: Number of files left to be processed in order to complete this job

files_total.description: Total number of files that will be processed during this job (this will be close but not exact)

throughput_overall.description: Overall average throughput in bytes per second of data copied since the beginning of the job

throughput_current.description: Average throughput in bytes per second of data copied in the last one minute

queued_snapshot_count.description: The number of snapshots from linked snapshot policies awaiting replication by this relationship

recovery_point_snapshot.description: The snapshot replicated by the last successful job. This field is null if no job has ever run successfully.

id.description: Unique identifier of the snapshot

timestamp.description: Creation timestamp of the snapshot, encoded as RFC 3339, which is a normalized subset of ISO 8601. See http://tools.ietf.org/rfc/rfc3339.txt, section 5.6 for ABNF.

in_delete.description: Whether or not the snapshot is in the process of being deleted

lock_key.description: The key that locks the policy-created snapshots for the specified target replication relationship. If set to null, the system does not lock the snapshots that the specified target replication relationship creates. Only snapshots created by a policy will be locked. Unless you configure an expiration on the snapshot policy on the target cluster, the system does not lock snapshots. If you reverse the relationship (switch the source and the target), the new target does not use this lock key. To enable snapshot locking, you must configure the new target separately. However, if you revert the reversed relationship (return the source and target to their original assignments), the system preserves the original target replication relationship lock key. Unless you reverse the relationship, you cannot disable or delete a lock key while a target replication relationship uses the key. If you disable or delete a lock key while the relationship is reversed and you then revert the reversal, the original source-target relationship has no lock key until you configure a new one.

post.summary: Revert target directory to the latest recovery point to ensure that it is in a point-in-time consistent state. Then disconnect the specified target replication relationship, breaking the relationship with the source and making the target directory writable. The revert action may take some time to complete. If the relationship is later reconnected, any changes made to the target directory since the relationship was disconnected will be reverted upon reconnecting.

bytes_total.description: Total number of bytes that will be processed during this job (this will be close but not exact)

files_unchanged.description: Number of files not copied because they didn't change

files_remaining.description: Number of files left to be processed in order to complete this job

files_total.description: Total number of files that will be processed during this job (this will be close but not exact)

throughput_overall.description: Overall average throughput in bytes per second of data copied since the beginning of the job

throughput_current.description: Average throughput in bytes per second of data copied in the last one minute

recovery_point_snapshot.description: The snapshot that the last successful job replicated. If no replication job has ever run successfully, this field is set to null.

id.description: Unique identifier of the snapshot

timestamp.description: Creation timestamp of the snapshot, encoded as RFC 3339, which is a normalized subset of ISO 8601. See http://tools.ietf.org/rfc/rfc3339.txt, section 5.6 for ABNF.

directory_name.description: Snapshot directory name, as would be seen in the .snapshot directory over SMB or NFS.

source_file_id.description: Source directory of the snapshot

created_by_policy.description: This snapshot was created by a policy. The name of that policy will be stored in the name field in place of a user-defined name.

expiration.description: Time at which snapshot will be expired. Empty string if no expiration time set. Encoded as RFC 3339, which is a normalized subset of ISO 8601. See http://tools.ietf.org/rfc/rfc3339.txt, section 5.6 for ABNF.

in_delete.description: Whether or not the snapshot is in the process of being deleted

lock_key.description: The key that locks the policy-created snapshots for the specified target replication relationship. If set to null, the system does not lock the snapshots that the specified target replication relationship creates. Only snapshots created by a policy will be locked. Unless you configure an expiration on the snapshot policy on the target cluster, the system does not lock snapshots. If you reverse the relationship (switch the source and the target), the new target does not use this lock key. To enable snapshot locking, you must configure the new target separately. However, if you revert the reversed relationship (return the source and target to their original assignments), the system preserves the original target replication relationship lock key. Unless you reverse the relationship, you cannot disable or delete a lock key while a target replication relationship uses the key. If you disable or delete a lock key while the relationship is reversed and you then revert the reversal, the original source-target relationship has no lock key until you configure a new one.

post.summary: Make the target directory read-only and revert any changes made to the target directory since the latest recovery point. Then reconnect the specified target replication relationship with its source directory. The revert action may take some time to complete before replication is resumed.

id.description: Unique identifier of the replication relationship

state.description:
Current state of replication relationship:
 * `AWAITING_AUTHORIZATION` - AWAITING_AUTHORIZATION,
 * `DISCONNECTED` - DISCONNECTED,
 * `DISCONNECTING` - DISCONNECTING,
 * `ENDED` - ENDED,
 * `ESTABLISHED` - ESTABLISHED,
 * `RECONNECTING` - RECONNECTING,
 * `REESTABLISHING` - REESTABLISHING

end_reason.description: If the relationship has ENDED, this states the reason. Otherwise, this field is empty

source_root_read_only.description: Whether the source directory is read-only

source_address.description: The previously connected source IP address

source_port.description: Network port previously used to replicate to on the source

target_root_read_only.description: Whether the target directory is read-only

job_state.description:
Current state of the job:
 * `REPLICATION_NOT_RUNNING` - REPLICATION_NOT_RUNNING,
 * `REPLICATION_RUNNING` - REPLICATION_RUNNING

job_start_time.description: If the job state is REPLICATION_RUNNING, this is the time that the job started, encoded as RFC 3339

recovery_point.description: The time that the last successful job started, encoded as RFC 3339

error_from_last_job.description: The error message from the previous job. If the previous job succeeded or no job has ever run, this field will be empty

duration_of_last_job.description: The elapsed execution time of the previous job, in nanoseconds. If no job has ever run, this field will be null.

target_root_id.description: File ID of the target directory

replication_job_status.description: Information about the progress of a job. This field is null if there is no job status available.

percent_complete.description: Percent of way through the job, computed from a weighting of data and files processed

estimated_seconds_remaining.description: Estimated number of seconds remaining in the job, derived from percent_complete. This may be null if there is no estimate.

bytes_unchanged.description: Number of bytes not copied because they didn't change

bytes_remaining.description: Number of bytes left to be processed in order to complete this job

bytes_total.description: Total number of bytes that will be processed during this job (this will be close but not exact)

files_remaining.description: Number of files left to be processed in order to complete this job

files_total.description: Total number of files that will be processed during this job (this will be close but not exact)

get.summary: Get information about all privileges.
List all roles.

name.description: Name of the role. Role names are case-insensitive and may not contain whitespace.

items.description:
Privileges the role has been granted:
 * `PRIVILEGE_ACCESS_TOKENS_READ` - View any access tokens present in the system,
 * `PRIVILEGE_ACCESS_TOKENS_WRITE` - Create or delete access tokens for any user in the system,
 * `PRIVILEGE_AD_READ` - Read Qumulo Active Directory settings,
 * `PRIVILEGE_AD_USE` - Use Qumulo's APIs for performing queries against Active Directory,
 * `PRIVILEGE_AD_WRITE` - Modify Qumulo Active Directory settings,
 * `PRIVILEGE_ANALYTICS_READ` - Read cluster analytics,
 * `PRIVILEGE_AUDIT_READ` - Read audit settings,
 * `PRIVILEGE_AUDIT_WRITE` - Modify audit settings,
 * `PRIVILEGE_AUTH_CACHE_READ` - Internal-Only: Read authentication cache settings,
 * `PRIVILEGE_AUTH_CACHE_WRITE` - Internal-Only: Modify authentication cache settings,
 * `PRIVILEGE_CAPACITY_READ` - View the capacity clamp value.,
 * `PRIVILEGE_CAPACITY_WRITE` - Set the capacity clamp value.,
 * `PRIVILEGE_CHECKSUMMING_READ` - View the status of checksumming,
 * `PRIVILEGE_CLUSTER_READ` - View nodes, disks, protection status, and SSL certificate,
 * `PRIVILEGE_CLUSTER_WRITE` - Modify cluster settings and disk/identify LEDs,
 * `PRIVILEGE_DEBUG` - Internal-Only: Perform debug operations on the cluster,
 * `PRIVILEGE_DISK_ERROR_READ` - Internal-Only: Read disk error threshold and status.,
 * `PRIVILEGE_DISK_ERROR_WRITE` - Internal-Only: Modify disk error threshold and revive rejected disks.,
 * `PRIVILEGE_DNS_READ` - Read DNS settings,
 * `PRIVILEGE_DNS_USE` - Perform DNS lookups,
 * `PRIVILEGE_DNS_WRITE` - Modify DNS settings,
 * `PRIVILEGE_ENCRYPTION_READ` - View the status of at-rest-encryption,
 * `PRIVILEGE_ENCRYPTION_WRITE` - Rotate encryption keys for clusters with at-rest-encryption,
 * `PRIVILEGE_FILE_FULL_ACCESS` - Provides full access to all files regardless of permissions,
 * `PRIVILEGE_FILE_READ_ACCESS` - Provides read access to all files regardless of permissions,
 * `PRIVILEGE_FS_ATTRIBUTES_READ` - Read file system statistics,
 * `PRIVILEGE_FS_DELETE_TREE_READ` - View the status of directory tree delete operations,
 * `PRIVILEGE_FS_DELETE_TREE_WRITE` - Use directory tree delete API. Granting this privilege allows the deletion of any file or directory on the cluster. File and directory permissions are not taken into account. Not required for `rm -r`.,
 * `PRIVILEGE_FS_FILE_LOCK_WRITE` - Set or extend file lock retention periods and legal holds.,
 * `PRIVILEGE_FS_KEY_MANAGEMENT_READ` - Read and list public keys for various FS security features.,
 * `PRIVILEGE_FS_KEY_MANAGEMENT_WRITE` - Create and manage public keys for various FS security features.,
 * `PRIVILEGE_FS_LOCK_READ` - View NLM and SMB locks and waiters,
 * `PRIVILEGE_FS_LOCK_WRITE` - Release NLM and SMB locks,
 * `PRIVILEGE_FS_SETTINGS_READ` - View file system permissions settings,
 * `PRIVILEGE_FS_SETTINGS_WRITE` - Modify file system permissions mode,
 * `PRIVILEGE_FTP_READ` - View FTP status and settings,
 * `PRIVILEGE_FTP_WRITE` - Modify FTP status and settings,
 * `PRIVILEGE_IDENTITY_CONFIG_READ` - Read and list identity configurations.,
 * `PRIVILEGE_IDENTITY_CONFIG_WRITE` - Modify identity configurations.,
 * `PRIVILEGE_IDENTITY_MAPPING_READ` - Get AD/LDAP User Defined Mappings,
 * `PRIVILEGE_IDENTITY_MAPPING_WRITE` - Set AD/LDAP User Defined Mappings,
 * `PRIVILEGE_IDENTITY_READ` - Use Qumulo's identity lookup and translation APIs,
 * `PRIVILEGE_IDENTITY_WRITE` - Modify identity attributes and clear authentication cache,
 * `PRIVILEGE_KERBEROS_KEYTAB_READ` - View Kerberos keytab,
 * `PRIVILEGE_KERBEROS_KEYTAB_WRITE` - Modify Kerberos keytab,
 * `PRIVILEGE_KERBEROS_SETTINGS_READ` - Read Kerberos settings,
 * `PRIVILEGE_KERBEROS_SETTINGS_WRITE` - Modify Kerberos settings,
 * `PRIVILEGE_KV_READ` - DEPRECATED: Read and delete KV store entries for all users,
 * `PRIVILEGE_LDAP_READ` - View LDAP settings,
 * `PRIVILEGE_LDAP_USE` - Use Qumulo's APIs for performing LDAP queries,
 * `PRIVILEGE_LDAP_WRITE` - Modify LDAP settings,
 * `PRIVILEGE_LICENSE_READ` - Get the cluster's license status.,
 * `PRIVILEGE_LOCAL_GROUP_READ` - View local groups and members,
 * `PRIVILEGE_LOCAL_GROUP_WRITE` - Modify local groups and membership,
 * `PRIVILEGE_LOCAL_USER_READ` - Get information about local users,
 * `PRIVILEGE_LOCAL_USER_WRITE` - Create and modify all local users,
 * `PRIVILEGE_METRICS_CONFIG_READ` - View metrics configuration,
 * `PRIVILEGE_METRICS_CONFIG_WRITE` - Modify metrics configuration,
 * `PRIVILEGE_METRICS_READ` - Get all metrics,
 * `PRIVILEGE_NETWORK_IP_ALLOCATION_READ` - View network IP address allocations,
 * `PRIVILEGE_NETWORK_READ` - Read network status and settings,
 * `PRIVILEGE_NETWORK_WRITE` - Modify network configuration,
 * `PRIVILEGE_NFS_EXPORT_READ` - View configuration of NFS exports,
 * `PRIVILEGE_NFS_EXPORT_WRITE` - Create, modify, and delete NFS exports,
 * `PRIVILEGE_NFS_SETTINGS_READ` - Internal-Only: View NFS server settings,
 * `PRIVILEGE_NFS_SETTINGS_WRITE` - Internal-Only: Modify NFS server settings,
 * `PRIVILEGE_OBJECT_STORAGE_URIS_READ` - View the object storage URIs.,
 * `PRIVILEGE_OBJECT_STORAGE_URIS_WRITE` - Add new object storage URIs.,
 * `PRIVILEGE_PORTAL_GLOBAL_READ` - View global portal settings and status,
 * `PRIVILEGE_PORTAL_HUB_READ` - View hub portal relationship status and configuration,
 * `PRIVILEGE_PORTAL_HUB_WRITE` - Authorize, modify, and delete hub portal relationships. Granting this privilege allows authorizing proposed relationships. Depending on existing file and directory permissions, this privilege can allow remote access to local data under the hub root directory.,
 * `PRIVILEGE_PORTAL_SPOKE_EVICT` - Remove cached files and directories from a spoke portal. Qumulo Core recaches the removed files or directories upon access.,
 * `PRIVILEGE_PORTAL_SPOKE_READ` - View spoke portal relationship status and configuration,
 * `PRIVILEGE_PORTAL_SPOKE_WRITE` - Create, modify, and delete spoke portal relationships. Granting this privilege allows creating spoke portal root directories. Depending on existing file permissions, this privilege can allow local access to remote files and directories.,
 * `PRIVILEGE_POWER_CYCLE` - Shutdown and reboot nodes,
 * `PRIVILEGE_QUOTA_READ` - View all file system quotas,
 * `PRIVILEGE_QUOTA_WRITE` - Create, modify, and delete file system quotas,
 * `PRIVILEGE_REBOOT_READ` - View Reboot Status,
 * `PRIVILEGE_REBOOT_USE` - Perform Reboots,
 * `PRIVILEGE_RECONCILER_READ` - View reconciler status and metrics,
 * `PRIVILEGE_REPLICATION_OBJECT_READ` - View object store relationship settings and status,
 * `PRIVILEGE_REPLICATION_OBJECT_WRITE` - Create, modify, and delete object store relationships. Granting this privilege allows overwriting existing data, replicating, and potentially accessing any data on the cluster regardless of file and directory permissions.,
 * `PRIVILEGE_REPLICATION_REVERSE_RELATIONSHIP` - Reverse a source and target relationship,
 * `PRIVILEGE_REPLICATION_SOURCE_READ` - View source relationship settings and status,
 * `PRIVILEGE_REPLICATION_SOURCE_WRITE` - Create, modify, and delete source relationships. Granting this privilege allows replicating and potentially accessing any data on the cluster regardless of file and directory permissions.,
 * `PRIVILEGE_REPLICATION_TARGET_READ` - View target relationship settings and status,
 * `PRIVILEGE_REPLICATION_TARGET_WRITE` - Create, modify, and delete target relationships. Granting this privilege allows overwriting any data on the cluster regardless of file and directory permissions.,
 * `PRIVILEGE_ROLE_READ` - View roles and assignments,
 * `PRIVILEGE_ROLE_WRITE` - Create and modify roles and assignments,
 * `PRIVILEGE_S3_BUCKETS_READ` - View all S3 buckets and bucket policies present in the system,
 * `PRIVILEGE_S3_BUCKETS_WRITE` - Create or delete any S3 bucket in the system, and create, delete, or modify policies for any S3 bucket in the system. Subject to having sufficient FS permissions.,
 * `PRIVILEGE_S3_CREDENTIALS_READ` - View any S3 access key present in the system,
 * `PRIVILEGE_S3_CREDENTIALS_WRITE` - Create or delete S3 access keys for any user in the system,
 * `PRIVILEGE_S3_SETTINGS_READ` - View S3 server settings,
 * `PRIVILEGE_S3_SETTINGS_WRITE` - Modify S3 server settings,
 * `PRIVILEGE_S3_UPLOADS_READ` - View all S3 uploads present in the system. This will override a bucket policy that denies the user this permission.,
 * `PRIVILEGE_S3_UPLOADS_WRITE` - Abort S3 uploads in the system. This will override a bucket policy that denies the user this permission.,
 * `PRIVILEGE_SAML_SETTINGS_READ` - View SAML integration settings,
 * `PRIVILEGE_SAML_SETTINGS_WRITE` - Modify SAML integration settings,
 * `PRIVILEGE_SERVICE_PUBLIC_KEYS_READ` - Internal-Only: Read public keys,
 * `PRIVILEGE_SERVICE_PUBLIC_KEYS_WRITE` - Internal-Only: Write public keys,
 * `PRIVILEGE_SMB_FILE_HANDLE_READ` - List open SMB file handles,
 * `PRIVILEGE_SMB_FILE_HANDLE_WRITE` - Force close an open SMB file handle,
 * `PRIVILEGE_SMB_SESSION_READ` - List logged on SMB sessions,
 * `PRIVILEGE_SMB_SESSION_WRITE` - Force close a logged on SMB session,
 * `PRIVILEGE_SMB_SHARE_READ` - View configuration of SMB shares and SMB server settings,
 * `PRIVILEGE_SMB_SHARE_WRITE` - Create, modify, and delete SMB shares and SMB server settings,
 * `PRIVILEGE_SNAPSHOT_CALCULATE_USED_CAPACITY_READ` - Recalculate capacity usage of snapshots,
 * `PRIVILEGE_SNAPSHOT_DIFFERENCE_READ` - View the changes between snapshots,
 * `PRIVILEGE_SNAPSHOT_LOCK` - Lock or unlock snapshots. Configure snapshot policies to lock or unlock snapshots.,
 * `PRIVILEGE_SNAPSHOT_POLICY_READ` - View snapshot policies and status,
 * `PRIVILEGE_SNAPSHOT_POLICY_WRITE` - Create, modify, and delete snapshot policies,
 * `PRIVILEGE_SNAPSHOT_READ` - List snapshots and view their status and cached capacity. Does not affect the visibility of the virtual `.snapshot` directories,
 * `PRIVILEGE_SNAPSHOT_WRITE` - Create, modify, and delete snapshots,
 * `PRIVILEGE_SUPPORT_READ` - View support configuration and status,
 * `PRIVILEGE_SUPPORT_WRITE` - Modify cloud-based monitoring and remote management,
 * `PRIVILEGE_TENANT_READ` - View any tenant information,
 * `PRIVILEGE_TENANT_WRITE` - Create, edit or delete tenants,
 * `PRIVILEGE_TEST_ONLY` - Test only actions,
 * `PRIVILEGE_TIME_READ` - View time and time settings,
 * `PRIVILEGE_TIME_WRITE` - Modify time settings,
 * `PRIVILEGE_UNCONFIGURED_NODE_READ` - List unconfigured Qumulo nodes,
 * `PRIVILEGE_UPGRADE_READ` - View upgrade configuration and status,
 * `PRIVILEGE_UPGRADE_WRITE` - Perform upgrades,
 * `PRIVILEGE_WEB_UI_SETTINGS_WRITE` - Modify web UI settings

 * `PRIVILEGE_REBOOT_READ` - View Reboot Status,
 * `PRIVILEGE_REBOOT_USE` - Perform Reboots,
 * `PRIVILEGE_RECONCILER_READ` - View reconciler status and metrics,
 * `PRIVILEGE_REPLICATION_OBJECT_READ` - View object store relationship settings and status,
 * `PRIVILEGE_REPLICATION_OBJECT_WRITE` - Create, modify, and delete object store relationships. Granting this privilege allows overwriting existing data, replicating, and potentially accessing any data on the cluster regardless of file and directory permissions.,
 * `PRIVILEGE_REPLICATION_REVERSE_RELATIONSHIP` - Reverse a source and target relationship,
 * `PRIVILEGE_REPLICATION_SOURCE_READ` - View source relationship settings and status,
 * `PRIVILEGE_REPLICATION_SOURCE_WRITE` - Create, modify, and delete source relationships. Granting this privilege allows replicating and potentially accessing any data on the cluster regardless of file and directory permissions.,
 * `PRIVILEGE_REPLICATION_TARGET_READ` - View target relationship settings and status,
 * `PRIVILEGE_REPLICATION_TARGET_WRITE` - Create, modify, and delete target relationships. Granting this privilege allows overwriting any data on the cluster regardless of file and directory permissions.,
 * `PRIVILEGE_ROLE_READ` - View roles and assignments,
 * `PRIVILEGE_ROLE_WRITE` - Create and modify roles and assignments,
 * `PRIVILEGE_S3_BUCKETS_READ` - View all S3 buckets and bucket policies present in the system,
 * `PRIVILEGE_S3_BUCKETS_WRITE` - Create or delete any S3 bucket in the system, and create, delete, or modify policies for any S3 bucket in the system. Subject to having sufficient FS permissions.,
 * `PRIVILEGE_S3_CREDENTIALS_READ` - View any S3 access key present in the system,
 * `PRIVILEGE_S3_CREDENTIALS_WRITE` - Create or delete S3 access keys for any user in the system,
 * `PRIVILEGE_S3_SETTINGS_READ` - View S3 server settings,
 * `PRIVILEGE_S3_SETTINGS_WRITE` - Modify S3 server settings,
 * `PRIVILEGE_S3_UPLOADS_READ` - View all S3 uploads present in the system. This will override a bucket policy that denies the user this permission.,
 * `PRIVILEGE_S3_UPLOADS_WRITE` - Abort S3 uploads in the system. This will override a bucket policy that denies the user this permission.,
 * `PRIVILEGE_SAML_SETTINGS_READ` - View SAML integration settings,
 * `PRIVILEGE_SAML_SETTINGS_WRITE` - Modify SAML integration settings,
 * `PRIVILEGE_SERVICE_PUBLIC_KEYS_READ` - Internal-Only: Read public keys,
 * `PRIVILEGE_SERVICE_PUBLIC_KEYS_WRITE` - Internal-Only: Write public keys,
 * `PRIVILEGE_SMB_FILE_HANDLE_READ` - List open SMB file handles,
 * `PRIVILEGE_SMB_FILE_HANDLE_WRITE` - Force close an open SMB file handle,
 * `PRIVILEGE_SMB_SESSION_READ` - List logged on SMB sessions,
 * `PRIVILEGE_SMB_SESSION_WRITE` - Force close a logged on SMB session,
 * `PRIVILEGE_SMB_SHARE_READ` - View configuration of SMB shares and SMB server settings,
 * `PRIVILEGE_SMB_SHARE_WRITE` - Create, modify, and delete SMB shares and SMB server settings,
 * `PRIVILEGE_SNAPSHOT_CALCULATE_USED_CAPACITY_READ` - Recalculate capacity usage of snapshots,
 * `PRIVILEGE_SNAPSHOT_DIFFERENCE_READ` - View the changes between snapshots,
 * `PRIVILEGE_SNAPSHOT_LOCK` - Lock or unlock snapshots. Configure snapshot policies to lock or unlock snapshots.,
 * `PRIVILEGE_SNAPSHOT_POLICY_READ` - View snapshot policies and status,
 * `PRIVILEGE_SNAPSHOT_POLICY_WRITE` - Create, modify, and delete snapshot policies,
 * `PRIVILEGE_SNAPSHOT_READ` - List snapshots and view their status and cached capacity. Does not affect the visibility of the virtual `.snapshot` directories,
 * `PRIVILEGE_SNAPSHOT_WRITE` - Create, modify, and delete snapshots,
 * `PRIVILEGE_SUPPORT_READ` - View support configuration and status,
 * `PRIVILEGE_SUPPORT_WRITE` - Modify cloud-based monitoring and remote management,
 * `PRIVILEGE_TENANT_READ` - View any tenant information,
 * `PRIVILEGE_TENANT_WRITE` - Create, edit or delete tenants,
 * `PRIVILEGE_TEST_ONLY` - Test only actions,
 * `PRIVILEGE_TIME_READ` - View time and time settings,
 * `PRIVILEGE_TIME_WRITE` - Modify time settings,
 * `PRIVILEGE_UNCONFIGURED_NODE_READ` - List unconfigured Qumulo nodes,
 * `PRIVILEGE_UPGRADE_READ` - View upgrade configuration and status,
 * `PRIVILEGE_UPGRADE_WRITE` - Perform upgrades,
 * `PRIVILEGE_WEB_UI_SETTINGS_WRITE` - Modify web UI settings

 * `PRIVILEGE_CLUSTER_WRITE` - Modify cluster settings and disk/identify LEDs,
 * `PRIVILEGE_DEBUG` - Internal-Only: Perform debug operations on the cluster,
 * `PRIVILEGE_DISK_ERROR_READ` - Internal-Only: Read disk error threshold and status.,
 * `PRIVILEGE_DISK_ERROR_WRITE` - Internal-Only: Modify disk error threshold and revive rejected disks.,
 * `PRIVILEGE_DNS_READ` - Read DNS settings,
 * `PRIVILEGE_DNS_USE` - Perform DNS lookups,
 * `PRIVILEGE_DNS_WRITE` - Modify DNS settings,
 * `PRIVILEGE_ENCRYPTION_READ` - View the status of at-rest-encryption,
 * `PRIVILEGE_ENCRYPTION_WRITE` - Rotate encryption keys for clusters with at-rest-encryption,
 * `PRIVILEGE_FILE_FULL_ACCESS` - Provides full access to all files regardless of permissions,
 * `PRIVILEGE_FILE_READ_ACCESS` - Provides read access to all files regardless of permissions,
 * `PRIVILEGE_FS_ATTRIBUTES_READ` - Read file system statistics,
 * `PRIVILEGE_FS_DELETE_TREE_READ` - View the status of directory tree delete operations,
 * `PRIVILEGE_FS_DELETE_TREE_WRITE` - Use directory tree delete API. Granting this privilege allows the deletion of any file or directory on the cluster. File and directory permissions are not taken into account. Not required for `rm -r`.,
 * `PRIVILEGE_FS_FILE_LOCK_WRITE` - Set or extend file lock retention periods and legal holds.,
 * `PRIVILEGE_FS_KEY_MANAGEMENT_READ` - Read and list public keys for various FS security features.,
 * `PRIVILEGE_FS_KEY_MANAGEMENT_WRITE` - Create and manage public keys for various FS security features.,
 * `PRIVILEGE_FS_LOCK_READ` - View NLM and SMB locks and waiters,
 * `PRIVILEGE_FS_LOCK_WRITE` - Release NLM and SMB locks,
 * `PRIVILEGE_FS_SETTINGS_READ` - View file system permissions settings,
 * `PRIVILEGE_FS_SETTINGS_WRITE` - Modify file system permissions mode,
 * `PRIVILEGE_FTP_READ` - View FTP status and settings,
 * `PRIVILEGE_FTP_WRITE` - Modify FTP status and settings,
 * `PRIVILEGE_IDENTITY_CONFIG_READ` - Read and list identity configurations.,
 * `PRIVILEGE_IDENTITY_CONFIG_WRITE` - Modify identity configurations.,
 * `PRIVILEGE_IDENTITY_MAPPING_READ` - Get AD/LDAP User Defined Mappings,
 * `PRIVILEGE_IDENTITY_MAPPING_WRITE` - Set AD/LDAP User Defined Mappings,
 * `PRIVILEGE_IDENTITY_READ` - Use Qumulo's identity lookup and translation APIs,
 * `PRIVILEGE_IDENTITY_WRITE` - Modify identity attributes and clear authentication cache,
 * `PRIVILEGE_KERBEROS_KEYTAB_READ` - View Kerberos keytab,
 * `PRIVILEGE_KERBEROS_KEYTAB_WRITE` - Modify Kerberos keytab,
 * `PRIVILEGE_KERBEROS_SETTINGS_READ` - Read Kerberos settings,
 * `PRIVILEGE_KERBEROS_SETTINGS_WRITE` - Modify Kerberos settings,
 * `PRIVILEGE_KV_READ` - DEPRECATED: Read and delete KV store entries for all users,
 * `PRIVILEGE_LDAP_READ` - View LDAP settings,
 * `PRIVILEGE_LDAP_USE` - Use Qumulo's APIs for performing LDAP queries,
 * `PRIVILEGE_LDAP_WRITE` - Modify LDAP settings,
 * `PRIVILEGE_LICENSE_READ` - Get the cluster's license status.,
 * `PRIVILEGE_LOCAL_GROUP_READ` - View local groups and members,
 * `PRIVILEGE_LOCAL_GROUP_WRITE` - Modify local groups and membership,
 * `PRIVILEGE_LOCAL_USER_READ` - Get information about local users,
 * `PRIVILEGE_LOCAL_USER_WRITE` - Create and modify all local users,
 * `PRIVILEGE_METRICS_CONFIG_READ` - View metrics configuration,
 * `PRIVILEGE_METRICS_CONFIG_WRITE` - Modify metrics configuration,
 * `PRIVILEGE_METRICS_READ` - Get all metrics,
 * `PRIVILEGE_NETWORK_IP_ALLOCATION_READ` - View network IP address allocations,
 * `PRIVILEGE_NETWORK_READ` - Read network status and settings,
 * `PRIVILEGE_NETWORK_WRITE` - Modify network configuration,
 * `PRIVILEGE_NFS_EXPORT_READ` - View configuration of NFS exports,
 * `PRIVILEGE_NFS_EXPORT_WRITE` - Create, modify, and delete NFS exports,
 * `PRIVILEGE_NFS_SETTINGS_READ` - Internal-Only: View NFS server settings,
 * `PRIVILEGE_NFS_SETTINGS_WRITE` - Internal-Only: Modify NFS server settings,
 * `PRIVILEGE_OBJECT_STORAGE_URIS_READ` - View the object storage URIs.,
 * `PRIVILEGE_OBJECT_STORAGE_URIS_WRITE` - Add new object storage URIs.,
 * `PRIVILEGE_PORTAL_GLOBAL_READ` - View global portal settings and status,
 * `PRIVILEGE_PORTAL_HUB_READ` - View hub portal relationship status and configuration,
 * `PRIVILEGE_PORTAL_HUB_WRITE` - Authorize, modify, and delete hub portal relationships. Granting this privilege allows authorizing proposed relationships. Depending on existing file and directory permissions, this privilege can allow remote access to local data under the hub root directory.,

 * `PRIVILEGE_QUOTA_READ` - View all file system quotas,
 * `PRIVILEGE_QUOTA_WRITE` - Create, modify, and delete file system quotas,
 * `PRIVILEGE_REBOOT_READ` - View Reboot Status,

 * `PRIVILEGE_REPLICATION_SOURCE_WRITE` - Create, modify, and delete source relationships. Granting this privilege allows replicating and potentially accessing any data on the cluster regardless of file and directory permissions.,
 * `PRIVILEGE_REPLICATION_TARGET_READ` - View target relationship settings and status,
 * `PRIVILEGE_REPLICATION_TARGET_WRITE` - Create, modify, and delete target relationships. Granting this privilege allows overwriting any data on the cluster regardless of file and directory permissions.,
 * `PRIVILEGE_ROLE_READ` - View roles and assignments,

 * `PRIVILEGE_S3_BUCKETS_READ` - View all S3 buckets and bucket policies present in the system,

 * `PRIVILEGE_SAML_SETTINGS_READ` - View SAML integration settings,
 * `PRIVILEGE_SAML_SETTINGS_WRITE` - Modify SAML integration settings,
 * `PRIVILEGE_SERVICE_PUBLIC_KEYS_READ` - Internal-Only: Read public keys,
 * `PRIVILEGE_SERVICE_PUBLIC_KEYS_WRITE` - Internal-Only: Write public keys,

items.description:
Privileges the role has been granted:
 * `PRIVILEGE_ACCESS_TOKENS_READ` - View any access tokens present in the system,
 * `PRIVILEGE_ACCESS_TOKENS_WRITE` - Create or delete access tokens for any user in the system,
 * `PRIVILEGE_AD_READ` - Read Qumulo Active Directory settings,
 * `PRIVILEGE_AD_USE` - Use Qumulo's APIs for performing queries against Active Directory,
 * `PRIVILEGE_AD_WRITE` - Modify Qumulo Active Directory settings,
 * `PRIVILEGE_ANALYTICS_READ` - Read cluster analytics,
 * `PRIVILEGE_AUDIT_READ` - Read audit settings,
 * `PRIVILEGE_AUDIT_WRITE` - Modify audit settings,
 * `PRIVILEGE_AUTH_CACHE_READ` - Internal-Only: Read authentication cache settings,
 * `PRIVILEGE_AUTH_CACHE_WRITE` - Internal-Only: Modify authentication cache settings,
 * `PRIVILEGE_CAPACITY_READ` - View the capacity clamp value.,
 * `PRIVILEGE_CAPACITY_WRITE` - Set the capacity clamp value.,
 * `PRIVILEGE_CHECKSUMMING_READ` - View the status of checksumming,
 * `PRIVILEGE_CLUSTER_READ` - View nodes, disks, protection status, and SSL certificate,
 * `PRIVILEGE_CLUSTER_WRITE` - Modify cluster settings and disk/identify LEDs,
 * `PRIVILEGE_DEBUG` - Internal-Only: Perform debug operations on the cluster,
 * `PRIVILEGE_DISK_ERROR_READ` - Internal-Only: Read disk error threshold and status.,
 * `PRIVILEGE_DISK_ERROR_WRITE` - Internal-Only: Modify disk error threshold and revive rejected disks.,
 * `PRIVILEGE_DNS_READ` - Read DNS settings,
 * `PRIVILEGE_DNS_USE` - Perform DNS lookups,
 * `PRIVILEGE_DNS_WRITE` - Modify DNS settings,
 * `PRIVILEGE_ENCRYPTION_READ` - View the status of at-rest-encryption,
 * `PRIVILEGE_ENCRYPTION_WRITE` - Rotate encryption keys for clusters with at-rest-encryption,
 * `PRIVILEGE_FILE_FULL_ACCESS` - Provides full access to all files regardless of permissions,
 * `PRIVILEGE_FILE_READ_ACCESS` - Provides read access to all files regardless of permissions,
 * `PRIVILEGE_FS_ATTRIBUTES_READ` - Read file system statistics,
 * `PRIVILEGE_FS_DELETE_TREE_READ` - View the status of directory tree delete operations,
 * `PRIVILEGE_FS_DELETE_TREE_WRITE` - Use directory tree delete API. Granting this privilege allows the deletion of any file or directory on the cluster. File and directory permissions are not taken into account. Not required for `rm -r`.,
 * `PRIVILEGE_FS_FILE_LOCK_WRITE` - Set or extend file lock retention periods and legal holds.,
 * `PRIVILEGE_FS_KEY_MANAGEMENT_READ` - Read and list public keys for various FS security features.,
 * `PRIVILEGE_FS_KEY_MANAGEMENT_WRITE` - Create and manage public keys for various FS security features.,
 * `PRIVILEGE_FS_LOCK_READ` - View NLM and SMB locks and waiters,
 * `PRIVILEGE_FS_LOCK_WRITE` - Release NLM and SMB locks,
 * `PRIVILEGE_FS_SETTINGS_READ` - View file system permissions settings,
 * `PRIVILEGE_FS_SETTINGS_WRITE` - Modify file system permissions mode,
 * `PRIVILEGE_FTP_READ` - View FTP status and settings,
 * `PRIVILEGE_FTP_WRITE` - Modify FTP status and settings,
 * `PRIVILEGE_IDENTITY_CONFIG_READ` - Read and list identity configurations.,
 * `PRIVILEGE_IDENTITY_CONFIG_WRITE` - Modify identity configurations.,
 * `PRIVILEGE_IDENTITY_MAPPING_READ` - Get AD/LDAP User Defined Mappings,
 * `PRIVILEGE_IDENTITY_MAPPING_WRITE` - Set AD/LDAP User Defined Mappings,
 * `PRIVILEGE_IDENTITY_READ` - Use Qumulo's identity lookup and translation APIs,
 * `PRIVILEGE_IDENTITY_WRITE` - Modify identity attributes and clear authentication cache,
 * `PRIVILEGE_KERBEROS_KEYTAB_READ` - View Kerberos keytab,
 * `PRIVILEGE_KERBEROS_KEYTAB_WRITE` - Modify Kerberos keytab,
 * `PRIVILEGE_KERBEROS_SETTINGS_READ` - Read Kerberos settings,
 * `PRIVILEGE_KERBEROS_SETTINGS_WRITE` - Modify Kerberos settings,
 * `PRIVILEGE_KV_READ` - DEPRECATED: Read and delete KV store entries for all users,
 * `PRIVILEGE_LDAP_READ` - View LDAP settings,
 * `PRIVILEGE_LDAP_USE` - Use Qumulo's APIs for performing LDAP queries,
 * `PRIVILEGE_LDAP_WRITE` - Modify LDAP settings,
 * `PRIVILEGE_LICENSE_READ` - Get the cluster's license status.,
 * `PRIVILEGE_LOCAL_GROUP_READ` - View local groups and members,
 * `PRIVILEGE_LOCAL_GROUP_WRITE` - Modify local groups and membership,
 * `PRIVILEGE_LOCAL_USER_READ` - Get information about local users,
 * `PRIVILEGE_LOCAL_USER_WRITE` - Create and modify all local users,
 * `PRIVILEGE_METRICS_CONFIG_READ` - View metrics configuration,
 * `PRIVILEGE_METRICS_CONFIG_WRITE` - Modify metrics configuration,
 * `PRIVILEGE_METRICS_READ` - Get all metrics,
 * `PRIVILEGE_NETWORK_IP_ALLOCATION_READ` - View network IP address allocations,
 * `PRIVILEGE_NETWORK_READ` - Read network status and settings,
 * `PRIVILEGE_NETWORK_WRITE` - Modify network configuration,
 * `PRIVILEGE_NFS_EXPORT_READ` - View configuration of NFS exports,
 * `PRIVILEGE_NFS_EXPORT_WRITE` - Create, modify, and delete NFS exports,
 * `PRIVILEGE_NFS_SETTINGS_READ` - Internal-Only: View NFS server settings,
 * `PRIVILEGE_NFS_SETTINGS_WRITE` - Internal-Only: Modify NFS server settings,
 * `PRIVILEGE_OBJECT_STORAGE_URIS_READ` - View the object storage URIs.,
 * `PRIVILEGE_OBJECT_STORAGE_URIS_WRITE` - Add new object storage URIs.,
 * `PRIVILEGE_PORTAL_GLOBAL_READ` - View global portal settings and status,
 * `PRIVILEGE_PORTAL_HUB_READ` - View hub portal relationship status and configuration,
 * `PRIVILEGE_PORTAL_HUB_WRITE` - Authorize, modify, and delete hub portal relationships. Granting this privilege allows authorizing proposed relationships. Depending on existing file and directory permissions, this privilege can allow remote access to local data under the hub root directory.,
 * `PRIVILEGE_PORTAL_SPOKE_EVICT` - Remove cached files and directories from a spoke portal. Qumulo Core recaches the removed files or directories upon access.,
 * `PRIVILEGE_PORTAL_SPOKE_READ` - View spoke portal relationship status and configuration,
 * `PRIVILEGE_PORTAL_SPOKE_WRITE` - Create, modify, and delete spoke portal relationships. Granting this privilege allows creating spoke portal root directories. Depending on existing file permissions, this privilege can allow local access to remote files and directories.,
 * `PRIVILEGE_POWER_CYCLE` - Shutdown and reboot nodes,
 * `PRIVILEGE_QUOTA_READ` - View all file system quotas,
 * `PRIVILEGE_QUOTA_WRITE` - Create, modify, and delete file system quotas,
 * `PRIVILEGE_REBOOT_READ` - View Reboot Status,
 * `PRIVILEGE_REBOOT_USE` - Perform Reboots,
 * `PRIVILEGE_RECONCILER_READ` - View reconciler status and metrics,
 * `PRIVILEGE_REPLICATION_OBJECT_READ` - View object store relationship settings and status,
 * `PRIVILEGE_REPLICATION_OBJECT_WRITE` - Create, modify, and delete object store relationships. Granting this privilege allows overwriting existing data, replicating, and potentially accessing any data on the cluster regardless of file and directory permissions.,
 * `PRIVILEGE_REPLICATION_REVERSE_RELATIONSHIP` - Reverse a source and target relationship,
 * `PRIVILEGE_REPLICATION_SOURCE_READ` - View source relationship settings and status,
 * `PRIVILEGE_REPLICATION_SOURCE_WRITE` - Create, modify, and delete source relationships. Granting this privilege allows replicating and potentially accessing any data on the cluster regardless of file and directory permissions.,
 * `PRIVILEGE_REPLICATION_TARGET_READ` - View target relationship settings and status,
 * `PRIVILEGE_REPLICATION_TARGET_WRITE` - Create, modify, and delete target relationships. Granting this privilege allows overwriting any data on the cluster regardless of file and directory permissions.,
 * `PRIVILEGE_ROLE_READ` - View roles and assignments,
 * `PRIVILEGE_ROLE_WRITE` - Create and modify roles and assignments,
 * `PRIVILEGE_S3_BUCKETS_READ` - View all S3 buckets and bucket policies present in the system,
 * `PRIVILEGE_S3_BUCKETS_WRITE` - Create or delete any S3 bucket in the system, and create, delete, or modify policies for any S3 bucket in the system. Subject to having sufficient FS permissions.,
 * `PRIVILEGE_S3_CREDENTIALS_READ` - View any S3 access key present in the system,
 * `PRIVILEGE_S3_CREDENTIALS_WRITE` - Create or delete S3 access keys for any user in the system,
 * `PRIVILEGE_S3_SETTINGS_READ` - View S3 server settings,
 * `PRIVILEGE_S3_SETTINGS_WRITE` - Modify S3 server settings,
 * `PRIVILEGE_S3_UPLOADS_READ` - View all S3 uploads present in the system. This will override a bucket policy that denies the user this permission.,
 * `PRIVILEGE_S3_UPLOADS_WRITE` - Abort S3 uploads in the system. This will override a bucket policy that denies the user this permission.,
 * `PRIVILEGE_SAML_SETTINGS_READ` - View SAML integration settings,
 * `PRIVILEGE_SAML_SETTINGS_WRITE` - Modify SAML integration settings,
 * `PRIVILEGE_SERVICE_PUBLIC_KEYS_READ` - Internal-Only: Read public keys,
 * `PRIVILEGE_SERVICE_PUBLIC_KEYS_WRITE` - Internal-Only: Write public keys,
 * `PRIVILEGE_SMB_FILE_HANDLE_READ` - List open SMB file handles,
 * `PRIVILEGE_SMB_FILE_HANDLE_WRITE` - Force close an open SMB file handle,
 * `PRIVILEGE_SMB_SESSION_READ` - List logged on SMB sessions,
 * `PRIVILEGE_SMB_SESSION_WRITE` - Force close a logged on SMB session,
 * `PRIVILEGE_SMB_SHARE_READ` - View configuration of SMB shares and SMB server settings,
 * `PRIVILEGE_SMB_SHARE_WRITE` - Create, modify, and delete SMB shares and SMB server settings,
 * `PRIVILEGE_SNAPSHOT_CALCULATE_USED_CAPACITY_READ` - Recalculate capacity usage of snapshots,
 * `PRIVILEGE_SNAPSHOT_DIFFERENCE_READ` - View the changes between snapshots,
 * `PRIVILEGE_SNAPSHOT_LOCK` - Lock or unlock snapshots. Configure snapshot policies to lock or unlock snapshots.,
 * `PRIVILEGE_SNAPSHOT_POLICY_READ` - View snapshot policies and status,
 * `PRIVILEGE_SNAPSHOT_POLICY_WRITE` - Create, modify, and delete snapshot policies,
 * `PRIVILEGE_SNAPSHOT_READ` - List snapshots and view their status and cached capacity. Does not affect the visibility of the virtual `.snapshot` directories,
 * `PRIVILEGE_SNAPSHOT_WRITE` - Create, modify, and delete snapshots,
 * `PRIVILEGE_SUPPORT_READ` - View support configuration and status,
 * `PRIVILEGE_SUPPORT_WRITE` - Modify cloud-based monitoring and remote management,
 * `PRIVILEGE_TENANT_READ` - View any tenant information,
 * `PRIVILEGE_TENANT_WRITE` - Create, edit or delete tenants,
 * `PRIVILEGE_TEST_ONLY` - Test only actions,
 * `PRIVILEGE_TIME_READ` - View time and time settings,
 * `PRIVILEGE_TIME_WRITE` - Modify time settings,
 * `PRIVILEGE_UNCONFIGURED_NODE_READ` - List unconfigured Qumulo nodes,
 * `PRIVILEGE_UPGRADE_READ` - View upgrade configuration and status,
 * `PRIVILEGE_UPGRADE_WRITE` - Perform upgrades,
 * `PRIVILEGE_WEB_UI_SETTINGS_WRITE` - Modify web UI settings
